title.native: Fate/Grand Order -終局特異点 冠位時間神殿ソロモン-
title.romaji: Fate/Grand Order: Shuukyoku Tokuiten - Kani Jikan Shinden Solomon
title.english: Fate/Grand Order Final Singularity - Grand Temple of Time: Solomon

description:
After battling their way through all seven Singularities, the Chaldea Security Organization has finally arrived at the endpoint of the Grand Order: The Final Singularity, Grand Temple of Time: Solomon.

Now is the time to defeat the root of all evil, Solomon, the King of Mages. Now is the time to reclaim the future.

With the final operation looming large, Romani Archaman considers the choices he will soon have to make, Mash Kyrielight dwells on life’s limitations, and Fujimaru prepares to receive a new Mystic Code.

All their many encounters have led to this moment as Fujimaru and Mash at last embark on their final operation...

[Source: Aniplex USA]
synonyms: เฟท แกรนด์ ออเดอร์ เดอะมูฟวี่ : จุดเอกฐานสุดท้าย มหาวิหารแห่งกาลเวลา โซโลมอน

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Crossover
tags.description: Centers around the placement of two or more otherwise discrete fictional characters, settings, or universes into the context of a single story.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Pirates
tags.description: Prominently features sea-faring adventurers branded as criminals by the law.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Time Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features time-traveling or other time-warping phenomena.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Spearplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of spears in combat.

tags.name: Archery
tags.description: Centers around the sport of archery, or prominently features the use of archery in combat.

tags.name: Battle Royale
tags.description: Centers around a fierce group competition, often violent and with only one winner.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

node.description:
__[The BAMBOO BROOM (Blog)](http://www.remus.dti.ne.jp/~takeucto/)__

A Japanese author best known for writing the visual novels Tsukihime and Fate/stay night. Renowned for a unique style of storytelling and prose, Nasu is amongst the most prominent visual novelists in Japan. 

Together with high school classmate and friend, [Takeuchi Takashi](https://anilist.co/staff/99054/Takashi-Takeuchi), Nasu formed [TYPE-MOON](https://anilist.co/staff/97582) in 2000, originally as a doujin group to create the visual novel Tsukihime. It soon gained immense popularity, much of which is attributed to Nasu's unique style of storytelling. A sequel to Tsukihime, Kagetsu Tohya, was released on August 2001. 

54563 Kinokonasu is named after him

__[The BAMBOO BROOM (Blog)](http://www.remus.dti.ne.jp/~takeucto/)__

Takashi Takeuchi is a Japanese artist, noted as the co-founder of Japanese visual novel and anime development and production enterprise [TYPE-MOON](https://anilist.co/staff/97582), and for his illustrations on TYPE-MOON's visual novels, Tsukihime and Fate/stay night.

__[The BAMBOO BROOM (Blog)](http://www.remus.dti.ne.jp/~takeucto/)__

A Japanese author best known for writing the visual novels Tsukihime and Fate/stay night. Renowned for a unique style of storytelling and prose, Nasu is amongst the most prominent visual novelists in Japan. 

Together with high school classmate and friend, [Takeuchi Takashi](https://anilist.co/staff/99054/Takashi-Takeuchi), Nasu formed [TYPE-MOON](https://anilist.co/staff/97582) in 2000, originally as a doujin group to create the visual novel Tsukihime. It soon gained immense popularity, much of which is attributed to Nasu's unique style of storytelling. A sequel to Tsukihime, Kagetsu Tohya, was released on August 2001. 

54563 Kinokonasu is named after him

__Headquarters:__ Tokyo, Japan

__[Website](http://typemoon.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/tmitterofficial)__

__Introduction:__
Type-Moon is a Japanese game company was founded by artist [Takashi Takeuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/99054/Takashi-Takeuchi) and writer [Kinoko Nasu](https://anilist.co/staff/98250/Kinoko-Nasu), who were also schoolmates. The names "TYPE-MOON" and "Notes." come from one of their early works, Notes..

__History:__
Originally formed as a Doujin Soft in 2000 and created the popular visual novel Tsukihime, but turned into a Commercial Organization on January 30, 2004 and in the same year, they released their PC-based eroge visual novel game Fate/stay night, which is their most well known title.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/miyafic)

The representative director of Capsule, a CG animation company

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Lownine)

Kazuma Kouda is a concept artist. He is best known as the concept artist for NieR: Automata. He has done artwork for Bayonetta 2, Pokémon: Let's Go Pikachu! and Fire Emblem: Three Houses.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/USUI_H)

Director of the Background Art Department at [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/CloverWorks).

Wanted to pursue a career in anime after having seen [Princess Mononoke](https://anilist.co/anime/164/) while still in high school. The art depiction of the movie's setting made her want to become a background artist. She entered the industry in 2002, and joined Studio Who, a background art studio ran by [Tsutomu Fujita](https://anilist.co/staff/147331/). Later she joined Studio Easter and worked on many of [A-1 Pictures](https://anilist.co/studio/561/)' projects, most notably making her debut as an art director on [Idolmaster](https://anilist.co/anime/10278/). She has since served as an art director on [Your Lie in April](https://anilist.co/anime/20665/), [Occultic;Nine](https://anilist.co/anime/21708/), [Horimiya](https://anilist.co/anime/124080/) among others.
A former Studio Easter employee. Debuted as an art director on [Guin Saga](https://anilist.co/anime/5041/).
Director of the Finishing Department at [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/3298914906)

Originating from [Imagin](https://anilist.co/studio/75/). Started off as a production manager.
